Reviews.Author: birder919
Reviews.Content: This is one great camera. I use it to snap photos of migrating birds passing through the area. The great zoom capabilities help me capture great pictures of distant subjects and the picture quality is great when doing so. The only complaint I have against the camera is that the auto focus has difficulties with very small objects with a distant back drop behind the subject, however I bet I can remedy this by looking through the manual and learning what setting the camera needs to be at to capture a perfect picture. Reviews.Title: Excellent results
Reviews.Author: S. Saunders
Reviews.Content: In the 3 or 4 months that I've owned it, I've challenged this camera, on a trip to Hawaii and to some places not far from home. I've used it at full-out zoom to photograph wildlife and at its widest angle for landscapes, and taken many photos under less than ideal lighting conditions. For what it is, it's been a champ. By that I mean, that it's not a DSLR, and if like me you also own a DSLR, you can't expect all the features and super quality images that a DSLR gives you.On the other hand, at this time I can't afford a super-zoom lens for my DSLR with the range of the zoom on this P500, and even if I could, the whole apparatus would be heavy and awkward to carry around.The photos I've gotten from this super-zoom point and shoot have not been disappointing. I haven't even worked much with the scene modes and other creative controls, because the auto settings have produced good results for me. It's light and not too bulky to carry around.The lens cap tends to fall off easily, and to avoid lens damage and accidental activation, I use a neoprene wrap to cover and protect the camera when it's not in use: Fotodiox Neoprene Zoom Camera Cover Sleeve (Travel Case) which fits the P500 nice and snug. I almost always carry this camera inside a large purse, tote bag, or backpack, so I don't need a dedicated camera bag for it. I also use a hand strap with it: OP/TECH USA 1801021 Cam Strap QD, instead of the strap supplied by Nikon. It's a personal preference and that strap is plenty strong for this camera.

Reviews.Title: Decent at a lot of things but ultimately disappointing
Reviews.Author: sbadger
Reviews.Content: Even for the price the images whether automatically or manually focused the images appear soft, even when I use programs like Lightroom 4.1 to try to sharpen them. After using it for a few months, I have moved on to a DSLR Canon 50D which gives me the results I am looking for. This camera offers a lot of good features but it doesn't perform more than average at any of them. There are no real strengths except in macro which it does moderately well. I do still appreciate it because I learned a lot from all the features it has and how they work but honestly if you want a long term purchase, get a real DSLR or another bridge camera. The best thing I can think about this camera is the ease of use and the screen display; the display is gorgeous and its actually a bit deceiving.The zoom abilities are impressive but again the image quality really is substandard when fully zoomed, even on a tripod. The video is also substandard as well, my Iphone4 gives me better quality and smoothness. 1080p lags and 720p does too from time to time; I originally thought it was just the memory card and upgraded it to a San Disk Extreme 32MBs and still saw no improvement.High Shutter Speeds and Burst Modes: Camera offers them but still are not impressive by any means. Get a DSLR if you want to truly catch moving subjects.Low light performance is poor but this isn't a DSLR either, I do wish the shutter wasn't limited be open for only 8 seconds. 30seconds would be a much more reasonable limit for night shots and a "bulb" setting would be preferred. Again this camera offers a lot of features but they were all done halfway, each of them fall short.I wanted this camera to be good, its a nice looking and fun to use but it does not offer the quality that it should. That is why I wouldn't recommend it to anybody who is on the fence between point-and-shoot and a full DSLR. I would just save for a good DSLR or at the very minimum pick a different camera in this price range. If Nikon actually would have offered less features and focused on the more important things like the image quality and video I believe this would have been a much better camera. It does a lot of things but nothing really well.

Reviews.Title: Convenient Size Camera with Great Zoom
Reviews.Author: Stuart Jacobson
Reviews.Content: The zoom range on this camera is fantastic.  I bought this camera for a trip where I did not want to take my large and heavy Canon EOS with its 28 to 200 mm zoom lens.  The camera served its purpose, but it is still not comparable to the Canon.  It's the same old delay problem from pressing the shutter button until the shutter actually operates.  I found this to be somewhat annoying on more than a few occasions.  It was also a little hard getting use to the zoom operation being only available with the push of a button, one way or the other.  Even though the zoom is electronic, it is still easier to turn the zoom lens on my Canon by hand, which allows me to frame my picture exactly like I want it.  With the electronic zoom, it often was back and forth several times until the zoom lens would stop where you wanted it to stop.  All in all, it is a good camera as long as you can deal with its downsides.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera for Price
Reviews.Author: S. Martin
Reviews.Content: I am staring out this review with the statement that I am not Tech Savy, so with some of the tech features, unfortunately I will not be able to review.  This review is simply from a laymans view.I am an amature photographer, and had (and still have) a NIKON N70 (35 MM format.)  When camera's went digital, I waited many years for the prices to come down.  Last year in February, I had purchased the D3100, for which hubby and I were to share! (Who was I kidding)  One of the reasons why I had chosen to get the NIKON D3100 was because of the extra lenses from the N70.  Within 2 months, I was faced with a decision to by a seperate camera for myself.One of the facts that I was faced with is that I enjoyed the D3100, but I didn't want to be bothered with carrying all the extra lenses, having to change them, etc.  I know I would loose intrest in my shot by the time I set up. (Hubby has more patients.)  I wanted a camera that I could treat like a point and shoot, but have the zoom capibility of a DSLR.  I went to local Photography store and to make a long story short, I ended up with the RED P500.I really have no regrets.  Some Cons are:  Battery life.  Our D3100 Battery hubby can take on average between 600 - 800, if not more, on one battery charge. P500 takes between 250 - 300 pictures on average per charge. (Colder weather it's less pics.) The charging time also takes a while.  Can take up to 4 - 8 hours to charge 1 battery.  I have not tried the video, so I can't comment.  Some Pros are the ZOOM.  I can get a lot Closer than some of the lenses my husband has.  By the time he switches lenses and focuses, I have already taken the shot, so portability is great. Focusing can be an issue the further out you go, but with a Tripod or a Monopod, they help.

Reviews.Author: JimD "JimD"
Reviews.Content: I have an old film type SLR but I am not that into cameras.  This is the 4th digital camera for me. I really like that the flash does not deploy until you tell it to.  My simpler cameras are always wanting to use the flash when it will not reach the object I am trying to get a picture of.  If you are looking for a camera of this type you should seriously consider this Nikon.  If you think you like it but are scared of somthing with manual exposure control, and aperature priority and shutter priority options as well as a couple automatic settings, you shouldn't be.  You don't have to use these features until you want to.  You can take nice pictures without ever understanding this but if you don't like something, they can be nice to have.

Reviews.Title: Good for novice photographer
Reviews.Author: geraldm
Reviews.Content: I purchased this item for Christmas for myself because I realized how much I love photography and wanted to take it up as a hobby. DSLRs at present do not suit my pocket and I was a bit hesitant to buy because I know absolutely nothing about photography, which was my decision to purchase a camera like this. A friend of mine suggested the Panasonic Lumix FZ series which I liked but I chose this one and thus far, I am beginning to enjoy photography. I purchased some photography books and some accessories for the camera and it has help to increase my interest in the field. The camera is pretty simple to use for a rookie and with the right guidance, can be used to learn the fundamentals while taking some pretty good shots. I'm looking forward though to "graduating" from this camera and purchasing a DSLR. When that time comes I'll sort that out but for now, I'd recommend this camera to anyone wanting to get into the field.

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMARA.PERIOD.
Reviews.Author: EL PADRINO
Reviews.Content: BEEN THRU ALOT OF CAMARAS AND SO FAR THIS IS THE BEST CAMARA I HAVE COME ACROSS.A LITTLE CONFUSING AT FIRST BUT AFTER PLAYING WITH THE CAMARA GOT THE HANG OF IT..

Reviews.Title: LOVE this camera
Reviews.Author: Claudia Martinez "latina69"
Reviews.Content: I'm not a pro at all, so this camera is perfect for me. I just love it, especially the incredible zoom it has. You can do a lot with this P500, I am learning everyday as I'm not so fond of reading manuals, so I browse through it every now and then. But believe me, it is a good camera if you enjoy taking pics and don't necessarily want to invest in a professional camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera So Far! Read the Manual!
Reviews.Author: K. Morse
Reviews.Content: We just bought this camera after spending a week or so reviewing all the different ones in this price range. Considered going for an entry level DSLR, but this camera can do so much more and the image quality is still really good. Here is what you have to realize though: only using the camera on its auto setting will leave you very disappointed. This camera can do so much more, but YOU HAVE TO TAKE TIME TO READ THE MANUAL and toy around with all the extra settings and features. Do that, and you will have an incredibly versatile digital camera.Want pictures of your kids? This camera can catch them in the midst of all their crazy antics, but not in the auto setting! Want pictures indoors at low light? It'll do that too, but not in the auto setting! Want action shots? Same thing! Seriously, before you get the camera and immediately think that it doesn't do any better than your old camera, spend a few hours with the manual. A little patience, and you'll be very happy with the quality.I'm barely even an amateur photographer, but once I dared to venture away from the "point and shoot" setting I have been extremely pleased and excited with the quality of the pictures I've been taking. Would they win awards? No, but now I can look at all those "memories" and not feel like my camera totally ruined them. In fact, I feel like it caught them as well as I could hope to!So don't be scared of all the reviews about image quality, no action shots, blurring, etc. Buy the camera, learn what it can do, experiment, and have fun!Honestly, my only con so far is that the manual is only on CD.

Reviews.Title: Great for Birding, but Missing Some Features
Reviews.Author: Dee N "tonipaw"
Reviews.Content: I received the P500 as my Christmas present to help with bird identification. It's been doing a great job, but at 16x optical zoom (at F8) and 64x digital zoom, it takes a very steady hand or a tripod to get clear shots at long focal lengths. Even then, we have been able to capture hand-held shots of birds 100'+ out with enough clarity for a positive ID even when we were not sure through our Nikon binoculars.I've also started doing some basic astronomical photography using the manual modes (including manual focus) on the P500 and have found it to be quite useful. Shots of the moon are clear enough to show the craters clearly and a long exposure of Jupiter showed the four Galilean moons, although with some streaking.Chromatic aberation is apparent at the long zoom settings, as is expected in a camera like this one. Image quality, especially with full digital zoom, is definitely a compromise.The HDR mode in backlighting is useful, but inconsistent. Fine details can be lost, even on a tripod.With such a long telephoto, any movement during exposure will cause smearing of the image. Without a remote release option, this means using the timer to do the release for maximum clarity.Shooting with maximum resolution and fine detail means large file sizes, so a fast SD card is a must with this camera. The minimum speed is Class 6, but I'd recommend Class 10 since the cost difference is minimal.Macro mode is useable, but not as good as some other compact cameras that I have. Of course, being able to get a clean shot of a humming bird at 15' is a real plus!While birding, carrying 15 lbs of camera gear can be quite exhausting. Having a small, light weight, versatile camera at hand can make the difference between capturing an image or wishing you had brought your camera with you.Will this replace a DSLR? Yes, if you don't mind losing some image quality for convenience. At the longest zoom settings, you probably won't be printing the images in large sizes to display on your wall, but you may end up with some prized images that you wouldn't have gotten any other way.

Reviews.Author: B. Marshall
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera with a longer range to it, and yet still be able to take up close pictures. This one fits the bill, does both quite nicly !! I am going to really enjoy learning the newer bells and whistles on this camera. The flip out screen on the back is especially useful to me since I have an arthritic neck condition.I would recommend this camera for the person that wants a little more for a point and shoot camera..

Reviews.Title: excelente

Reviews.Content: muy buen producto, con una muy alta calidad calidad de imagen y gran alcance del zoom. 100%recomendado a todos los que le interesa la fotografia. y de gran comodidad para el transporte

Reviews.Title: Absolutely Wonderful!
Reviews.Author: Millie P.
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my husband for his birhtday/Christmas present.  He reviewed many cameras over a long period of time and chose this one in red.  He is not a professional photographer but loves taking pictures.  It has a magnificent zoom, which he has used to photograph the moon at night and dusk. Reviews.Title: Love this camera!

Reviews.Content: I was in need for a new Digital Camera due to a car accident ruining my last one. I am a photography student and starting to take family pictures for family and friends. Reviews.Title: My wife loves it
Reviews.Author: William E. Schultheis
Reviews.Content: It was a birthday present for my wife and she is never without the camera.  She simply loves it and what she can do with this camera.  She said it was the best present she ever received.

Reviews.Title: Great

Reviews.Content: Great product, service and price, I have successful with my buy, this camera is faster and have full resolution picture, your zoom 36x allows to capture images and videos of excellent quality and makes shots that are difficult to perform with short zoom cameras.

Reviews.Title: Great decision!

Reviews.Content: I read reviews for this camera and the Cannon that compares to it, I took a few weeks to decide which one to get and so far I feel like I made a great decision! Reviews.Author: D. Vincent "Techgeek"
Reviews.Content: I have been searching for a long time for a camera to replace a Panasonic FZ30 that I really loved taking pictures with; problem was it only did SD video.  I sold it about a year ago and have regretted that ever since.  I nearly bought a T3I, but couldn't justify pulling the trigger on that much money, plus to get something close to an all in one zoom it was going to run me nearly $1,600 total.I looked at the Canon is30x and the Sony hx100v, but both had some major features that bugged me.  I really just didn't like the look and feel of the Canon and the Sony's sluggish zoom ring and forced picture review turned me off.  After playing with the P500 at target (my local target doesn't tether them so you can actually feel the real camera) I had to have it.The next day Amazon lowered the price by about $40 making it a no brainer. Reviews.Author: Pat N. Korsmeier "PennyN"
Reviews.Content: I received this camera only a couple of days before leaving for an extended trip to Yellowstone and Glacier National Parks, and how fortunate that was. With the 16 gig card, there were no worries that space would be a problem even with including quite a few videos.  Also having the iPad to "download" each day's photos provided excellent feedback as to improving shooting skills and reinforcing the max zoom capability.Overall, I am extremely pleased with the Nikon P500. } } } Length:: 1:16 Mins**Unfortunately Amazon limits videos to 100mb and auto-downgrades the quality for streaming purposes. Through this review I will have links to my sample videos on You tube. To get the videos to work, simply remove the spaces - sorry, the URL has to be mangled or else Amazon will zap it.**I had been awaiting the Nikon P500 for a while now, hoping it would be a worthy successor to my beloved Panasonic Lumix DMC-ZS7, which was my previous point-and-shoot. For stills I generally use my Canon EOS Rebel T2i DSLR, but when you're watching a concert sometimes all you want to do is point and click a single button. The Lumix ZS7 was great for this (see my other uploaded You tube videos), but it had some drawbacks - most noteably the limited 12x zoom and handicapped low-light performance. Note: I purchased the red version but the reviews don't seem to carry over.Auto-focus with video==============================Video: Sarah McLachlan singing "Awakenings" at the Chicago Theateryou tube . com / watch?v=YQ5PUe_amtMThe P500 had some nifty little tricks up its sleeve which made it sound ideal for concert-type photography. Unfortunately what's keeping it from being an awesome video camera is its incredibly slow auto-focus. At various points in my linked video, I move my focus from Sarah McLachlan to the various members in the band. At 1:50 I focus on Luke Doucet (the guitarist); he does not come completely into focus until 1:55. The slow auto-focus is really noticeable when changing zoom ratios. If you're at a static zoom and just panning the camera the auto-focus takes around ~1 second. If you zoom in or out, the focus takes an average of 3-to-4 seconds (2-4 in bright light).Compare the video from my original link to this one taken with the Panasonic Lumix ZS7:you tube . com / watch?v=2tHM392Ozyc (Sarah McLachlan singing "Awakenings" at the Austin City Music Hall)At around 1:04 in the ZS7 video I move from a non-zoom to a close up of Sarah McLachlan. Through the zoom process, the camera stays mostly in sharp focus unlike what you see with the P500.Now it should be noted that distance obviously comes into play here. With my ZS7 I was in the third row - less than fifteen feet from the stage and less than twenty feet away from Sarah. With my P500 in Chicago, I was on the front row of the second floor (Loge) which put me about forty-to-fifty feet away at an three-quarters angle to the stage. However the pre-focus light on my ZS7 was turned off (that giant red light), but turned on with the P500. In other words, these were not identical situations by any means.Vibration Reduction with video==============================Video: Sarah McLachlan singing "Building a Mystery" at the Chicago Theateryou tube . com / watch?v=UcsttYmp_jEAnother thing you may have noticed is that the vibration reduction while handheld isn't that spectacular. If you fast-forward in the above video, from 2:30 onward all video is being taken with the use of a monopod. It's only with the addition of the monopod that the video becomes "stable".Spot Metering (Contrast in low light)==============================Now, where the P500 shined was its handing of spot metering. Through much of the concert footage with my Lumix ZS7, the bright spotlight caused the highlights to just become washed out. The P500 with its CMOS sensor did a much better job handling the contrast and keeping the detail without allowing the lows and highs to become blown out. I added a shot in the customer gallery of a sample still I took with the P500 by the light of a single tea light so you can see the P500's stellar performance in low light.Sound==============================The P500 comes with two insert microphones above the flash (in order to record in stereo). When you're working with video in a quiet environment the zoom lens does create an audible "vrrrrrr *chuck!*" sound when in use - and it will make its way onto the audio track of your video. This may be annoying to the concert goer if the performer is singing a quiet or acoustic set with no amplifier. However if you're at a fully amped concert it's probably loud enough that you won't hear the internal mechanics of the camera in the audio. The sound quality sits firmly in the "ok" realm of fidelity. When I got home and listened to the audio from my concert I wasn't overly impressed as I thought it sounded rather hollow. Then again, you can't really expect to get studio quality sound from these types of built in microphones (no built-in camera mic has impressed me yet).Portability (Hideability?)==============================Make no mistake, the P500 is freaking huge. I've added a few shots of the camera in the customer photos gallery - I have the P500 sitting next to my ZS7 and my T2i (sorry for the quality of that shot, I ran out of things to take pictures with and had to make due with my camera phone) with the lens fully extended and without. If I do not attach a lens to my T2i, the P500 is actually larger than my DSLR. One of the things I didn't like about my Lumix ZS7 was that I thought it was too big to be a throw-in-your-pocket camera. Well, the P500 makes my ZS7 look freaking tiny.That being said, if you're planning on sneaking in a camera to a concert, this one'll be very hard to conceal - and when that lens is fully extended it's like holding up a giant neon sign that screams, "I HAVE A CAMERA!"Conclusion==============================My purpose in purchasing the P500 was to have a good concert buddy. The max zoom of 810mm was just insane and it let me hope that I could grab a good, tight shot of the performer even from the nosebleed section. Unfortunately the performance of the auto-focus in video mode makes me rethink even keeping this camera around. The 36x zoom is freaking awesome and the small things like the 240 frames per second slow-mo movie modes make it a very neat (expensive) toy. If you're planning on using this camera purely to take stills, it's a pretty good point-and-shoot. The image quality suffers even in that capacity though - as quite a few online reviews/blogs will attest too. If your hope was to have a good all around stills-and-video superzoom, the P500 isn't quite there yet. If Nikon can somehow fix the slow auto-focus by way of a firmware update and clean up the noise at the high-end of its zoom with stills, then this camera would be spectacular.And just to be clear, I am not advocating filming concerts when the artists forbid it.

Reviews.Title: NO MACRO CAPABILITY
Reviews.Author: Danyo
Reviews.Content: The Nikon P500 does not live up to it's specs & users manual. In close-up or macro focus mode it can focus down to 4 inches in the wide angle position to "three increments from max wide-angle." It does that. However, the manual also states that "At the zoom position that is three increments for the maximum wide-angle to the telephoto position, the camera can focus on subjects as close as 1 cm (0.4") from the lens". This is not true. The camera cannot focus on anything beyond that first three increments from max wide-angle. So if you are looking for a camera with macro capabilities this one doesn't even rate a look.My rating of 1-star is tied to this one quality that the P500 was supposed to have, but doesn't.

Reviews.Title: Initially liked it ... but then I actually used it!
Reviews.Author: Wine Junkie "Wine Junkie"
Reviews.Content: I was excited about this camera when I got it - specifically the feature that allows you to video and take pictures at the same time.  Very cool.  While that was very cool, the disappointing part of this camera was that it took bad pictures.I went to my kids assembly to give this little charmer a try.  Not only would it not focus for shots when I used the zoom (and unzoomed), but the shutter lag was terrible - it reminded me of my first digital camera from about 10 years ago ...slooooooow!  I missed all sorts of good shots (disappointing) - all the photos were BLURRY!! So, I tried several of the different modes on the camera to fix the problem - but, that didn't help at all.Bottom line:  Cute little camera, very light - neat video/photo feature.  But, if you are buying this camera to take pictures then you should find another one. I returned it the next day.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix P500
Reviews.Author: B. ELKINS
Reviews.Content: Camera is great Takes sharp pictures and is light weight It was a gift for my wife and she loves it

Reviews.Title: So sweeeeeet!
Reviews.Author: Death4u
Reviews.Content: This camera is great for bird photography.  The zoom was the selling point for me.  Even in my sometimes shaky hands it takes sweet pics from a LONG LONG LONG ways away.  This thing kicks my binoculars butt and snaps pictures to boot!

Reviews.Title: P500
Reviews.Author: lucas brosam
Reviews.Content: Great camera everyone says that my camera takes really good pictures but the battery life is less than desired just make sure you bring extra batteries.

Reviews.Title: Very good camera for its price
Reviews.Author: Sergio "Sergio Georgi"
Reviews.Content: I got this as a gift for a friend of mine and he's very happy with it. I should have purchased the black one but didn't pay attention that this was a RED one. Autofocus on this camera is very good and the tilt of the LCD helps a lot when you film or take pics. Camera is very light and it won't put much weight on you if you carry it on long trips.

Reviews.Title: Nikon P500 does NOT come with a Owner's Manual
Reviews.Author: Mr. Cosmic Ray
Reviews.Content: Nikon has gone cheapoo.  I have had Nikons before, and always appreciated their detailed manuals, with careful how-to lists. This P500 camera comes only with a "Quick Start" manual that is virtually useless after you learn how to insert the battery. For example, if you look for the self-timer, the manual says: "See page 139 of the Owner's Manual". That is it. No instructions, not even a clue as to where the control is. This pamphlet is really just an index for the real Owner's Manual.  The Owner's Manual is on an included CD. What good is that on a back-packing trip, or a boat trip? The manual on the CD is 253 pages long, and in some strange format with pages about 4" x 6". So if you try to print it out, you get an 1" thick manual with the pages in one corner. And at a cost of $25. This just pathetic from a company that used to stress quality.

Reviews.Title: Not worth the money for 36x
Reviews.Author: Tommy B. McDonell "Tommy a doctoral candidate...
Reviews.Content: I am a big fan of Nikon and I always want to get as close as I can get to birds, ducks, geese, and even far off mountains. However, I don't think this camera is worth the price for the 36x shot. Nikon's camera at 24 or 26 does just as good a job. With 36 you really need a tripod for that zoom.

Reviews.Title: ZOOM THAT UR EYE CAN'T BARELY SEE... GOOD CAMERA GET IT...

Reviews.Title: A disappointment thus far
Reviews.Author: CMB
Reviews.Content: At maximum zoom outdoors last evening (around 7 PM) and this morning (around 6 AM) (both times when there is enough light that I would walk the dogs by myself) my consistent experience was: 1) pictures turned out way too dark or completely black (I had some success mitigating this by using aperture priority with forced flash); 2) when holding the shutter halfway down to lock the focus, it took a LONG time for the focus to lock; and 3)almost every picture was out of focus.  It took great indoor shots and I did not see these issues at lesser zoom, but why do you buy an ultra-zoom camera?  Right now my impression is this is a great camera if you are going to the Grand Canyon with a tripod, but if you think you are going to hold the camera in your hands and catch anything moving (kids, animals) at maximum zoom, or get pictures of your kid's school play, you will be disappointed. Also, after taking about 100 pictures and maybe 30 seconds of video, the fully-charged battery was down by about 3/4 as best I could tell from the indicator.  This does not offer enough of an improvement over my Canon sx200IS (with 12x optical zoom) to justify $400.I think it's probably going back but I'll play with it a bit more and update my reviewUPDATE:  Further tests in bright sunlight today revealed the same: virtually impossible to get a shot that's in focus at maximum zoom without a tripod.  Plus I keep getting an error that "this card cannot be used" even though there's plenty of space on the card, it's a class 6 card, and it was working before.  If I turn off the camera, take the card out, put the card back in, and turn the camera back on, it works again, but seriously....

Reviews.Title: Nikon Fan A Bit Disappointed...
Reviews.Author: Gladius
Reviews.Content: The Nikon D40 was amazing.  This is pretty darn good, too, but must be compared to the Canon SX40.  The  Nikon is smaller (a good thing) and has a push button flash (amazingly the Canon does not).  Anyway, the Canon has a brighter LCD (neither is great but the Nikon's is just dark).  The same is true of the viewfinders --- glad to have but not very good on either.  More importantly, the Canon is MUCH faster --- especially as it has a Digic 5 processor (the vaunted G12 still has a Digic 4).  It also seems to have a somewhat easier time focusing when you're really out there with the lens.  The battery is bigger, too.  Build quality --- a bit better on this Canon (seems otherwise at first but a plastic piece on the Nikon has a loose glue hold).  The Canon starts at a surprisingly good f/2.7, too.  All that said the Nikon is cheaper --- $317 is just incredible for the lens alone.  If not for the speed difference, I'd probably prefer the Nikon as it is much cheaper.Don't get me wrong, with these lenses both probably needed to cut costs where they could.  Both are great --- one is just better.  But I'm keeping my Nikon D3100 --- a superb camera for the money that takes great shots.  At $550 (with good kit lens) DSLR --- just as amazing.It's a great time to buy a camera!!!  (Or a computer.)If you're going to own only one camera buy the Canon SX40 or Nikon P500.  They're that good.  (And stealthy with the 35x and 36x lenses --- no I'm not spying on anyone --- maybe if I were still 18!).Enjoy either!

Reviews.Title: Buena cámara pero con algunas fallas importantes
Reviews.Author: alonso
Reviews.Content: Anteriormente tuve una Panasonic de 6MP y 12x zoom óptico, así que con la Nikon P500, con el doble de megapixeles y el triple de zoom óptico creí que iba a hacer magia con las fotos...La verdad, es una magnífica cámara para fotos de personas, incluso en situaciones de poca luz sin flash se las ingenia para tomar buenas fotos sin que queden movidas, es solo cuestión de saber escoger los ajustes óptimos. Cone la P500 he logrado fotos de personas que con la Panasonic ni hubiera soñado, muy bien por ahí.Lo malo viene con las fotos más complejas. Soy aficionado a la fotpgrafía de fauna, principalmente aves, y he tenido problemas serios con el enfoque. En situaciones de poca luz a veces la cámara tarda 4-5 segundos en enfocar, y cuando lo hace generalmente no enfoca lo que quiero. Obviamente en esos 4-5 segundos el pájaro ya se fue lo cual me frustra bastante...Incluso en situaciones de buena luz, suele tener problemas al enfocar. Lo hace rápido y me parece que está justo en el blanco, pero al revisar la foto en grande resulta que está levemente borroso, lo cual es muy molesto pues creía que había tomado la foto perfecta. Tomen en cuenta que generalmente para fotografiar un ave hay que hacerlo entre árboles y ramas atravesadas, o bien con un fondo difícil. Pero aún así, esperaba un mejor rendimiento con el enfoque.El zoom es efectivo y muy bueno, solo que hay que tener buena luz, una velocidad de obturador de al menos 1/200 diría yo con 36x zoom porque naturalmente la imagen se mueve bastante a menos que se tenga un trípode.Muy buena para imágenes rápidas en ráfaga. Tiene varias opciones, a que más me gusta es la de ráfaga rápida, que toma unas 5 fotos en menos de un segundo. Al menos una no sale movida y eso me basta para efectos de las fotos de aves. Luego de la ráfaga tarda unos 3-4 segundos en guardar los datos (tengo SD calidad 10), lo cual me parece bastante aceptable.En términos generales, es excelente para fotografiar personas, increíble claridad, buen enfoque, buen zoom. Para fotos más complejas y en movimiento como con aves, el enfoque es deficiente.

Reviews.Title: Do not buy this camera
Reviews.Author: J. O. Connor "sailor person"
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for 2 months now and have used it in a number of envirnments. I am an amature photographer with 25 years expierence with Nikon SLR camears and have never gotten such sad reuslts from any thing Nikon. The camera does not focus or do proper exposures when zoomed out and can not focus while panning moving items like pets or moving cars. Any redution in light below bright daylight exagerates these problems. What is most frustrating is trying to deal with Nikon Support. You must fill out a form on line and then "submit" it - 9 of my last 10 tries did not send comments/questions or the pictures showing my problems. I called and was given an Email address  which kicked back as well stating it did not receiveing inbound Email.  I have now been told to send the camera in for a check out and repair - except I need to pay for repacking (they do not want me to use the box in came in ??)and shipping. This camnera may have been defective out of the box but the attitude of the tech support people is nothing less than condescending (and yes they are not in the US) (I have blown enough time trying to work with Nikon that I am now beyond my reatailers return period !!  I think the term is  "Screwed". It is an attractive camera whith great features and is fairly easy to use - but DAH! - just does not take decent pictures. If you want to go ahead with this camera Please go to any local dealer and test it before you buy it on line or anywhere. Just watch the focus on the LCD as  you zoom or pan.If they let you take your SD card and try some pictures while Zoomed or panning and under low light conditions. Also -note that the LCD is always exposed - asking for damage......  at $400 this should be a much better piece of kit - it is no way a point & shoot if that is what you are looking for..  John

Reviews.Title: Poor IQ @ 500-meters
Reviews.Author: Michael J. Costello
Reviews.Content: Hi,The IQ of the P500 at 500-meters is no better than the P100, so this puppy is going back. At 500-meters, I still haven't found a compact zoom lens camera that beats the IQ of the Canon SX10IS mounted with a TCON-17 teleconversion lens and I've tried all of the super zooms to date -- all of them -- including the $7,000 Carl Zeiss PhotoScope. I'm now excited about the new Sony Cybershot DSC-HX100V digital camera coming out on May 1, 2011. The Sony HX100 has 16MP, a 30x optical zoom lens with 7x digital zoom. Hopefully, the enormous 16MP will not affect IQ and the camera will accept the TCON-17 teleconversion lens. Although I'm excited about the new Sony, I've learned not to get too excited -- I've been disappointed more than once with these zoom lens cameras.Mike
